Stack, this sounds like an interesting approach and matches up well with
wh=
at I've been thinking. 
 
What communications layer would you be using?
 
-=
 Kris

-----Original Message-----
From: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
[ma=
ilto:archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of stack
Sent: 9. n=F3vembe=
r 2005 22:06
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [archive-craw=
ler] Handling identical documents from different
sites.


callforshadab wro=
te:

> How should this be handled in the clustered version (multiple machin=
es
> running Heritrix)?
>
What would you suggest?

One notion we've been ki=
cking around is having a fast and dumb server 
sitting in the middle of a c=
oordinated crawling cluster.  A processor 
hosted by alll machines would as=
k it if the content (hash) had already 
been seen. Such a server might also=
 be used to check if an URL is 
already-seen.  Though the crawl space is sp=
lit between crawlers, we 
might run a central server to guard against repea=
t fetches when queues 
are moved between machines, either because one machi=
ne is overloaded so 
we narrow range its responsible for off-loading to adj=
acent crawlers or 
because a crawler is picking up for a crashed crawler (I=
f I remember 
correctly, the ubicrawler folks in their paper allow that a f=
ew URLs may 
be mutiply fetched during the coming and going of crawlers flu=
x).

St.Ack
